hook and yarn weight for a small key chain size bird i use dk and a 3mm hook specifically sirdar happy cotton dk 43m/20g/47yds the pattern scales well using heavier yarn or using two or three strands held together and larger hooks see the adjustment on the beak p6 for heavier yarns for much bigger sizes use yarn instead of embroidery floss for the insignia/combadge 2 this pattern is worked in joined rounds working in continuous rounds will result in a slightly different appearance stitch counts do not include the slip_stitch ch1 join 3 for smoother colour transitions make the last yarn over of the stitch before the change in the new colour 4 add a key chain to the top or attach a loop of ribbon or chain crochet for a bauble i suggest leaving the demon wings off if it s going to spend a lot of time in a pocket or bag 5 chicken wings do not have to be secured but if being used as a key ring there will be less wear and tear if they are 6 surface crochet using the posts of stitches or where the bottom and top of two row meet as if they were the loops of stitches to crochet into 7 securing tails pass tails at least three times through the body for extra security take the starting and ending tails out through the same stitch tie with a double knot and push the knot and remaining tails back into the body through that same stitch 8 experiment with little embellishments to signify different races create brow ridges for worf by adding some embroidered lines to the forehead or smaller lines above the beak and a little earring for ro give other bajorans a brown uniform make data s eyes with gold yarn maybe add some pointy eyebrows for spock leave the comb off for a bolian mfadreileenindes & p2/8 madeleine & friends notes 8 pattern written using us terminology blo = back loop only working into the loop furthest from you chain = chain double_crochet = double_crochet uk treble_crochet decrease = decrease also called decrease single_crochet two together insert hook
